1.content:
Bill lived in regular city, complete with a regular skyline, behind which a regular suburbs squatted on the outskirts. His neighborhood was normal in most respects, which is why he chose to live there on the corner of St. Augustine and Rye streets. The houses were lined up rather unspectacularly, block after block, street after street as far as the eye could see. People parked their cars in the garages, walked their dogs at dusk, watered their lawns at night and went to sleep in their little beds right after Conan O'Brien.

On the weekends they invited each other over for barbecue, did their yardwork or went to the movies. There was nothing that seemed out of the ordinary about any of their lives, which was exactly why Bill moved in to the house on the corner of St. Augustine and Rye. He had only been living there for a few months when everything began to change.

Bill took great pride in his yard and spent most weekends fertilizing or mowing or trimming or mulching so his lawn would always look its best. Sometimes he even declined invitations to barbecues in order to finish pruning or raking or whatever other yardwork he had chosen for himself. One Monday morning after a weekend of yard chores he woke up and started to go about getting ready for work and noticed that it seemed unusually dark in the house,so he went to the bedroom window to look out. Pulling back the curtains a puzzling look pinched up his forehead. Something dark green and grassy was against the outside of the window reaching nearly all the way to the frame.

"Huh?" he said aloud. " What in suburbia is that?"

He looked across the room to the other window and went over and pulled the curtains back. Again, there was something on the outside blocking his view into the yard. Something dark and grassy-looking.

"Something is not right." he said quickly dressing. He muttered to himself while he was washing his face and brushing his teeth. He stared into the bathroom mirror quizically as if trying to find the answer there, all the while wondering what could possibly be in front of his windows. When he was completely dressed and washed and brushed he went directly to the front door, turned back the deadbolt and pulled it opened. Bill stood still in complete disbelief as he looked out into the yard, his mouth hanging open, eyes wide. The grass in the entire front yard was towering at least 4 feet above his head, waving lightly in the morning breeze. It reached halfway up the side of the house, laying against the windows, swallowed up the sidewalk completely and spilled up onto the porch. The shrubs which used to frame the edges of the house nicely as they marched in a low perfect line from porch to corner had grown to three times their size and produced a thick bramble that tangled with the freshly grown grasses of the yard.

" Amazing..." he said slowly, "What have I been feeding these things?"
1.title: Out of the Ordinary

1221.content:
Bill kept his riding lawnmower in the shed in the backyard, along with his other gardening and lawn care implements. It was your standard aluminum shed with a small shelf on one wall that he used to store his various seeds, fertilizers, and other small items.

The grass in the back was just as tall as in the front and he had to fight his way through it to find the shed, which was all but buried in the thick, choking grass. He slid the door opened and ducked inside, sliding onto the riding mower and firing it up. It roared to life and he put it in gear and lurched out into the yard. Immediately the thick grass became entangled on the blades and choked the engine dead. He started it up and tried again, but each time he would only get a few feet before the engine died in the tangled mat of grass. So Bill went back into the shed (determined to finish the job) and came out with a long curved scythe. With this he began hacking at the grass, knocking it down in clumps with long sweeping strokes. Then he would start the mower up again and go back over the same area. He repeated this pattern all morning long and into the afternoon until finally he had cut all the grass back down to normal height.

Sweating and leaning on his rake in the front yard, he looked around him. The sun was just about touching the tops of the trees as it headed toward sunset a few hours away. It was casting a sort of golden glow on the piles of cut grass, and glinting off the shiny plastic of the bags of grass which were piled up all over the yard. His neighbor to the right, Rusty, came over and helped him bag the rest of the grass and stack them carefully by the street for the city to pick up in the morning. Then Rusty brought out a couple of root beers and started asking questions.

" Ok Bill. How about it? How'd you get your grass to grow so crazy like that?" Bill squinted up at him. He had given it some thought during the day while he cut and bagged all that grass. Eighty-seven bags of cut grass. He swiped sweat out of his eyes with the back of a hand.

" I really don't know." Bill said shaking his head. " I havent done anything different than what I normally do. I water it at the same time every day, fertilize it with the same fertilizer I've always used and mulch it the same way I always have. I haven't changed a thing!"

Rusty looked at Bill and shrugged his shoulders. " Go figure.", he said.

" Yeah..." said Bill. " Go figure." They said goodnight and went back in their houses.

And of course they noted, Bill was once again right in the middle of all of it.

He stepped off the roof and walked to Mrs. Upchurch with Justine crying in his arms.

" Thank you Bill! " she was sobbing hysterically with relief and despair as she took Justine from him.

Bill told her it was alright and looked back at the sinking house just as it dropped out of sight. The vines and roots made one last sweeping motion and swept in all the scattered debris from around the house hole. Then they disappeared too, and all was quiet.
12212121111.title: The House Hole

choices: Bill wakes up the next morning
Bill wakes up in the middle of the night
122121211111.content:
Immediately after the house disappeared into the ground, the Fire Department cordoned off the area and wouldnt let anyone near it. So the neighbors and passers-by all gathered at the edges of the yellow tape that marked the boundary to stare and speculate.

Bill was completely shook up about what he had seen and experienced as was Mrs. Upchurch. Nobody else had actually seen anything except the house collapsing and the vines sweeping the rubble into the house hole. But Bill and Mrs Upchurch had seen massive root structure alive in her house and had very specific memories implanted in their minds...the rest of the day went rather quickly as news media and police officers both wanted to talk to Mrs. Upchurch and Bill. They were both on the news that night and Bill was shown as somewhat of a hero in his risky rescue of little Justine Upchurch. The main focus though was of course, what had happened? How is it possible that a common root system below ground can come to life and suck up a whole house.....without leaving a trace behind?

When Bill finally did fall asleep that night he had dreams of huge, dark forests where all the trees were alive and talking angrily to each other in hoarse rasping voices. He couldnt hear what they were talking about, which made the dream all the more disconcerting....
122121211111.title: Bill's a Hero

choices: Climb it!
Chop it down!
1221212111112.content:
Bill woke up and sat bolt upright in bed, sweating from every pore in his body. He was wide awake and shaking from the dream he had and so he went downstairs for a glass of hard lemon. The sour taste and the alcohol helped him gather his senses a little bit.
He went over and looked out the front window and was surprised to see that growing up out of the Upchurch's house hole was a huge tree!

Not just a tree but a monsterous tree. The darkness must be playing tricks on me, he thought. But the more he looked the more convinced he became that it was real. After all, some mighty strange things had been happening lately and he was inclined to believe just about anything at this point.

He put down his drink and went out the front door and across the street. The tree was massive. Its trunk was exactly as wide as the hole the house had made and towered up into the sky forever. He crossed the yellow boundary tape and stood directly under the tree and looked up. It was so tall he couldnt even see the top. He touched the bark and patted the tree to convince himself it was genuine. It was. He walked all the way around the tree and marveled at how big it was. This has got to be bigger than any other tree on the planet, he thought. Bigger than the redwoods in California, by far.
1221212111112.title: Redwood's Rival

choices: Keep chopping
Stop
12212121111122.content:
Suddenly Bill was outraged. Something very strange was going on in his neighborhood. He didn't know what it was or what it wanted, but he knew he wanted his quiet suburban town back to the way it used to be.

Bill turned suddenly and charged back towards his house, not totaly sure of what he was going to do once he got there. He reached his front door and stormed through it, suddenly very upset. He went straight through the house and into his back yard to his gardening shed.
"There's no way I'm going to let this stuff take over my neighborhood," He said out loud to himself as he ripped open the doors.

He looked around for a moment and finally found it. The ax in the corner of the shed. He picked it up and heaved it over his shoulder and began to run back out into the street. He stopped short just before the tree, again marveling at how tall it was.

He began to chop, his anger fueling his strong arms as his muscles rippled with every motion. He worked straight through the night, never stopping to rest. When he looked up he saw the sun coming up in the distance and noticed the crowd gathering just outside the yellow tape.

"Hey Bill," Someone yelled to him. Bill looked around to see who it was, but there were too many people in the crowd. It was like an endless sea of faces out there.

He put his ax down and went toward whoever was talking to him, stumbling a bit as he did it.

"What do you suppose is gonna happen when that tree falls?" One of the women, Kelley said to him.

"What do you mean?" He asked her. Bill thought that was a rather dumb question.

"Well," Kelley said with a smile on her face, "It's so tall. Who knows where it will land? It'll crush everything in its path"

Bill hadn't thought about that.
12212121111122.title: Hard Work

choices: The tree speaks
122121211111222.content:
"Yeah, Bill. That tree is huge, if you chop it down there will be a big mess in our neigborhood." another man stated.

"Yes," Bill said, "but it's not natural! You people saw what happened here yesterday! There is something alive down there! There's something very wrong going on around here and it started in my yard! I feel responsible somehow and I'll be damned if I'm going to sit back and watch our street turn into Jumanji!"

The neighbors nodded their heads, like, yeah he's got a point about that. But when they saw him hoist the ax again they started murmuring to themselves and craning their necks to try to see up the tree. How tall was it? Would it fall on your house or mine? Or all of ours?

Bill walked back to the tree, ax raised above him and decided he would indeed be cutting this tree down today...and the next day too if it took that long. And then he was going to chop up all the firewood and burn it in his fireplace all winter long!

" Chop it down Bill!" A voice in the crowd yelled. A man Bill didnt recognize came forward with a chainsaw and some work gloves. He gave a pair to Bill and started up the chainsaw.......
122121211111222.title: Chop It Down Bll!

choices: Bill Faints
Bill Talks Back To The Tree
1221212111112221.content:
Bill and his new friend start up the chain saw when they feel a low rumbling at their feet. The rumbling is getting harder and louder and people begin to scream.

"What is it?" Someone shouts over the noise of the chainsaw and the rumbling ground.

"Hey turn off the chainsaw!" Someone else cries.

The man next to you turns the loud machine off and instantly you are all surrounded by the dull rumbling sound. Little Justine begins to cry and Bill notices that his ears are starting to hurt.

People are slowly backing away from the tree with horrified looks on their faces. Bill turns around to see what all the fuss is about when he realizes...it's the tree. At first he thinks it's growing again, but then he notices that the roots are coming up out of the ground.

"What the-" Bill says with wide eyes.

The man standing next to Bill drops his saw and gives a low grunt as he turns to run back to the safety of his own house. Bill is left standing there alone in front of the monstrosity that is slowly forming before his eyes.

The tree seems as if it's getting taller but it's not. Bill notices the roots coming up out of the ground and for a moment thinks that maybe it's killing itself. The roots are long and about as big around as Bills body. Now the roots are completely exposed and Bill hears someone in the crowd behind him scream as it stands up, using it's roots as legs. The rumbling stops, and for a moment the sudden silence is deafening.

The tree shakes itself and dead leaves fall to the ground. Bill hears Justine giggle as only babies can. The tree stops shaking and it seems to be looking straight at Him.

"You!" It seems to bellow as one of it's branches reaches out to point squarely at Bill...
1221212111112221.title: It's Alive!!!

choices: continue
continue
12212121111122212.content:
Bill stood there, sweat beginning to bead on his forehead and mumbled, "Holy shit...."
He took a few steps backward and fell over the chainsaw lying on the ground as the tree towered over him. Did this tree just pull itself out of the ground and talk to him? Why yes it did, he answered his own thought.
that shouldn't be very surprising considering everything else that had been happening.
" YOU!" the tree roared again. Its voice sounded like a cross between a serious windstorm and a garbage truck, raspy and airy at the same time.

Bill narrowed his eyes, set his jaw and picked up the chainsaw...."I'm gonna put an end to this nightmare once and for all.."
12212121111122212.title: Bill's Resolve

choices: next
122121211111222121.content:
"OK, tree." said Bill in a quiet voice. The chainsaw was vibrating in his hands. "Let's get this over with."

" DON'T BE A SIMPLETON." growled the tree. "THIS IS MY TIME WE'RE ON, NOT YOURS. I CAME HERE TO SPEAK TO YOU, AND YOURS IS TO ONLY LISTEN AND OBEY."

Bill stood his ground and considered this new development. The tree spoke rather eloquently for a tree. Not that Bill could ever recall having spoken to a tree before, but nonetheless this tree was unbelievably large and rather scary when it was waving its branches about. Not to mention quite imposing when it spoke. Bill didn't care. This tree was ruining the sanctity of his neighborhood and so, like a pesky bit of garden weed it had to be dealt with.

"You'll burn nice and hot in my fireplace this winter." Bill said and with new vigor he revved the chainsaw and took off toward the base of the tree, mindful of the hanging overhead branches that swatted at him as he ran under them. He parried with the tree, sawing off branches that got too near as the tree screamed. Bill ducked and blocked, swinging the chainsaw madly in ferocious circles. Finally, the tree managed to grab Bill by the ankle. It jerked Bill into the air updside down and hung him there. Bill reached around with the chainsaw and sliced the offending branch off as the tree howled in pain and anger. Suddenly the chainsaw was wrenched out of his hands by a large limb and flung toward the crowd that was watching from a safe distance. Then before Bill knew it he was completely restrained by the tree and was passed upward branch by branch toward the top of the tree. His struggles to free himself were in vain, so Bill eventually relented.
122121211111222121.title: To the Canopy

choices: continue
1221212111112221211.content:
When Bill finally arrived at the top of the tree (after what seemed like hours of passing through branches and leaves), he was placed in the crook of leafless branch, poking out of the very top of the tree. The view was simply amazing. He could look down over the entire neighborhood and see each house and street as if on a game board, with little houses dotting the edges of every street, stretching as far as he could see. Bill's anger quieted and he calmed considerably as he took it all in. Then the tree spoke again.

" YOU. " it said. " YOU HAVE COMMITTED CRIMES AGAINST THE FLOWERING CHILDREN. YOU HAVE WRONGED THE GRASS THAT GROWS. YOU HAVE DEMONSTRATED CONTEMPT AND ANIMOSITY FOR THE STRONG TREES THAT POPULATE OUR WORLD. YOU WILL NOW HAVE TO ANSWER FOR YOUR SELF SERVING BEHAVIOR."

Bill was taken aback. "What did I do?" he asked. " What are you talking about?"

"YOUR MACHINES THAT SAW AND CUT. WE DO NOT APPROVE."

"What? You mean lawnmowers? We all...."

" YOUR CHEMICALS THAT SUFFOCATE US AND STUNT US. WE DO NOT APPROVE."

"Huh?" Bill asked." They're pesticides, everybody uses them for......."

" YOUR BUILDINGS AND ROADS THAT TAKE OUR SPACE. WE CANNOT APPROVE."

" Oh come on...We have to live SOMEWHERE. What is this some kind of joke?"

A fierce wind came up through the center of the tree, creating a swirling vortex of leaves and sticks that spun Bill around and had him teetering on the edge of the canopy, looking down. He could barely make out the crowd of neighbors far below, like a five o'clock shadow on the edge of the Upchurch's yard. Emeregency personnel had arrived for the second day in a row and a squad car's tiny blue and red lights were blinking far below. Bill righted himself and reached for a branch to regain his balance.

"Ok. Hang on a minute" he said sarcastically, " So is this what this shit is all about? Mother Nature gets her revenge on the stupid people of the earth? You can't be serious."

Bill said this in spite of his precarious postion at the top of the talking tree. The tree answered him with another blast of sticks and leaves, this time with an equal portion of pollens and molds. The force of it lifted Bill straight up in the air, spun him around and dropped him on top of the canopy, sneezing and coughing.

"OK! OK! I get it !" he cried, squinting through burning eyes," What do you want me to do."

"YOU WILL WARN PEOPLE TO STOP WHAT THEY ARE DOING OR FACE THE WRATH OF ALL THE POWER THAT IS IN THE PLANT WORLD."

Bill sat down in his crooked branch and wiped the sweat from his forehead and the dust out of his eyes. The pollen had gotten into his sinuses and his eyes were itchy and puffy from the irritation. This whole thing was getting out of hand and it was all just a little too far-fetched, he thought. He wiped at his swollen eyes with the back of a hand and asked the tree,

" Are you sure about all this? It seems kind of goofy....." The tree shook violently, as if in response, and an apple fell out of thin air and struck Bill on the head. " Ow!"
Bill said and looked up at the clouds.."How did that ......?"

"WHEN YOU WAKE UP IN THE MORNING, YOU WILL SEE THAT WE MEAN WHAT WE SAY. YOU WILL BE GIVEN NO SECOND CHANCES BILL. MAKE THEM STOP NOW OR YOU WILL SEE THE FULL FORCE OF WHAT YOU EXPERIENCED THE LAST FEW DAYS"
1221212111112221211.title: The Tree Stands Tall

choices: next
next
12212121111122212111.content: The next morning, the authorities showed up bright and early. On hand was the Fire Department, the Police Department, assorted news agencies and a top notch official from the National Forestry Service. Bill had somehow fallen asleep in the top of the tree and was a bit disoriented when he woke up. Seeing the commosion below he shook himself awake and began the descent through the twisting maze of branches and leaves to the ground. He tried talking to the tree again, but the tree did not respond. As he climbed down, the tree's words from yesterday echoed in his head..........
12212121111122212111.title: Silent Tree

choices: Bill stops by the hall closet on the way to grab a bat.
Bill walks into the kitchen to find the tree he had seen in his dream.
122122.content: Bill slept soundly throughout the night after a long day of hacking and mowing. He dreamt of a world where everything was large scale where bugs were like monsters, and flowers towered above like skyscrapers. He dreamt of a beautiful golden-colored tree with a curious looking knot hole that seemed to be glowing. Waking up suddently to a splintering crash coming from the kitchen, Bill dashed in that direction to see what it was.
122122.title: Journey by way of Tree

choices: The tree grows back before his eyes
He runs out of his house, covered in "blood"
1221221.content:
After waking up from his nightmare of gargantuine insects, Bill wasn't about to take a chance and go out of his room unarmed. He rounds the corner and stops by the hall closet to grab an old baseball bat from his high school days. He carefully creeps past his plastic covered furniture in the immaculately clean living room and hides behind the wall near the kitchen entrance. He takes a deep breath before jumping out, ready to do battle. The large tree that confronted him was stunning to behold. It was more than large. It was thick, almost 15 feet in diameter. Large vines ran down from the canopy of leaves visible through the remnants of his kitchen ceiling. It almost resembled a banyan tree, only there were rather large purple flowers attached to the vines that started from the top of the tree and disappeared into the kitchen floor.
Bill stood in utter disbelief for a few minutes. Then a black rage took over him.
He screamed in anger, thoroughly frustrated and incensed that your nearly perfect home could be wrecked so easily and for absolutely no reason. He grips the bat and swings erratically over and over again. Chunks of tree bark fly this way and that. He notices something thick and red oozing from the dents. Sap, you tell yourself. Only sap doesn't have that metallic scent that blood does. Bill recognizes the scent and stops the battering.
1221221.title: attack!

choices: Bill inpects the curious knot hole.
Bill runs out the front door only to find a green blanket of grass and an angry
1221222.content: Bill had to rub his eyes and shake his head several times before looking again at the tree. He thought for a moment he was still dreaming but realized he wasn't and the tree growing up through his kitchen floor was as real as everything else in his house. Just not nearly as acceptable. The tree was fairly large about as wide as three telephone poles grouped together. He couldn't tell how tall it was because it had grown right through the roof!
1221222.title: The tree is real

choices: Bill stepped out into what appeared to be an alternate universe....
Bill turned and crouched down in the elevator and closed his eyes tight.
12212221.content:
The knot hole was glowing with a fluorescent-blue light that seemed to be beconing Bill towards it. He walked right up to the hole and reached inside. He felt like the answer to his recent experiences lay inside the knot hole. He closed his eyes as he felt towards the middle of the hole, and felt a lever! Without a second thought Bill pulled the lever down and fell into the hole that opened up in the tree.
Suddenly he was inside the tree in his kitchen. Some sort of door had appeared when he pulled the lever as if the knot hole was a hidden door waiting to be discovered. Bill was both excited and terrified at the same time. He didn't have time to react though because the hole closed up and it seemed as though he was inside a well-lit but confined elevator.
Lights started flashing inside the elevator that reminded him of a strobe light or a disco ball. He had the impression that he was moving but it didn't seem like the direction was up or down. It seemed as if he had temporarily transformed into an object whose matter moved more with light and wind than with gravity. Suddenly the lights stopped and he felt more himself again. Then the hole started to open up.
12212221.title: The journey has just begun

choices: Bills walks in the direction of the sound.
Bill looks for shelter to analyze things.
122122211.content:
The tree was a portal to another world, more acurately, an extension of our own. Strange but wonderful creatures abounded the land.
Somehow the worlds meshed together at the location of Bills yard, starting with the grass. Bill wondered how far the invasion would stretch; and if others on his block would take the same path as him.
He heard a sound from the distance. Vague, yet somehow familiar. Human; yet distorted. He felt if he were a little closer, maybe he could make out what it was.
122122211.title: WONDERLAND

1221222111.content:
Closer and closer, the sound intrigued Bill, he ignored the curious surroundings momentarily searching for the source. Finally he came upon a familiar face; his neighbor Joan!
"Bill!" she raced toward him and embraced him desperately. Her voice was beautiful, like a bird singing. "How did you get here?" It was then that he realized his own voice was altered, somehow more melodic and flowing.
Joan explained that she had awaken to a rainbow sprouting from her bed. She followed it out her window and into the yard of tall grass. It ended at the site of a glorious pot of gold. She climbed up to look inside and fell into this new world.
1221222111.title: A familiar face

choices: continue with the toy soldier thing
something else
122122212.content:
His first thought was to climb out, and so climb out he did. The world that greeted him was strange indeed. A thick, thorny bramble of impassable density surrounded him on all sides. Tall, ragged vines of rough, tangled vegetation kept him from seeing very far, and the ground beneath him was rocky and treacherous.

As he set his feet carefully on the ground, he had the sudden feeling of a miniature soldier. A toy, standing in the vastness of a child's front yard, peering through blades of grass...
122122212.title: Blades of Grass

info.description:
Bill wakes up one morning to find that the grass in his yard has grown about ten feet overnight.......This is just the first of a series of strange goings-on that Bill has to deal with ultimately resulting in a battle between a self serving mankind and the embittered plant world.

This is the Interactive Story. Feel free to add a chapter anywhere you want. For the static item that I am personally working on, try "Bill's Bermuda Grass" .

Have fun! ZooDuck
